9.54.text: We all have a ticket in our back pocket:

15.07.text:
We don't know when we're going to use it,
but we know it's there.

19.89.text:
We're the only animal
born both unfinished --

26.51.text: and we are aware that we will die.

30.08.text:
We make or we try to make
choices about our life

37.24.text:
We're experiencing now
a new kind of life skill.

44.86.text:
Now, death has always been
in our gut, right?

47.84.text: It's always been in our mind.

49.82.text:
It's the core of life, but now
it's coming out of the closet.

54.04.text: We have to talk about it.

56.06.text:
Blame the baby boomers;
they always demand attention.

66.18.text:
I'm not a boomer;
I'm the tail end of the beats.

69.52.text:
I don't know how many of us
are still around.

74.31.text: One of the most important questions

76.29.text:
is not, "How will I die?"
or, "When will I die?"

79.08.text:
It is, "Will I have truly lived
before I die?"

84.63.text:
One of the most common laments
at deathbeds

88.58.text:
is, "I didn't live my life,
and now it's too late."

94.31.text: I want something more for you.

97.66.text:
In Japan, they have
karaoke bars and lounges

101.62.text:
where men go and they sing,
with tears coming down their faces,

108.12.text: with great passion, the same song.

112.10.text: The number one song is "I Did It My Way."

117.84.text:
And I think that emotion is because
they know in some part of themselves

124.38.text:
that it'll be very hard
to do it their way.

129.95.text:
The last thing my father said to me
before he committed suicide at 56

140.75.text: He gave me a gift; I didn't know it then,

144.11.text:
but it was a gift to look carefully
at my own life

147.75.text:
so I would not in turn
break my child's heart.

151.96.text:
And so I started trying to live
poet Mary Oliver's words,

157.64.text:
to, "Let the soft animal of my body
love what it loves."

166.38.text:
it lowers the hidden physical
and psychological costs

175.38.text:
If you could live
as if you were already dead --

181.79.text: -- you could make very different choices.

184.20.text: You realize that the very best deal,

186.68.text:
even the best revenge,
is a good life and a good death.

195.74.text:
understanding that there are
all sorts of limits.

200.12.text: That's why people, I think, who survive

202.49.text:
a life-threatening illness,
many of them say

206.04.text:
it was the best thing
that ever happened to them,

211.54.text:
It shocked them
into a different perspective

216.32.text:
So let's check you out.
Is your heart beating? Huh?

224.90.text: All right, take a deep breath.

230.72.text:
You can hike, you can dance, you can work,
you can sleep, you can love.

236.95.text: You still have the immense power of life.

243.32.text: The question is, how do we use it?

250.94.text:
it feels like what psychologists
describe as flow.

254.90.text: When you're using your highest skills --

258.44.text:
an intense challenge,
whether it's art, or music,

262.52.text:
or science, or skydiving,
or scuba, or mountain climbing,

268.24.text:
you want to go higher and deeper
and you feel fully alive.

279.71.text:
My friend Mike
became a quadriplegic at 24.

285.60.text: He came out of his despair

288.10.text:
when he realized that he still had
his passionate mind,

293.16.text:
that he could reach the state
of euphoria and focus

298.86.text: that is that state of flow.

304.07.text:
Now, can you recall a time
when you felt so happy, so excited?

310.22.text: Maybe you were hiking in Mount Rainier,

314.23.text:
I mean, if you leave Seattle,
you can see the Milky Way.

319.27.text: Maybe you've just finished a big project,

325.14.text:
And you may find yourself saying
for the first time,

329.26.text: "I feel I have enough; I feel complete."

333.95.text:
You might even go so far as to say,
"This would be a good day to die."

339.91.text:
But, no, no;
we always want more time, OK.

342.48.text:
So, promise me
you'll keep wearing your seat belt.

348.26.text:
A single moment of flow is,
it's like an "aha,"

352.98.text:
you know, that explosive moment
of understanding.

356.95.text:
What death awareness gives you
is a continuing state of flow.

363.31.text: You feel wholly alive; it feels wonderful.

371.34.text: That's why -- well, you know the French?

376.13.text:
which means "the little death,"
because you transcend yourself.

382.02.text:
A state of flow
lets you transcend yourself.

386.20.text:
Now, the opposite
of that happy, comfortable feeling,

391.79.text: is when you don't feel complete.

394.38.text:
You don't feel satisfied;
you feel anxious.

399.19.text:
You go for a walk and --
I call them "shame shots."

403.68.text:
You're just walking and then
something comes through your mind.

406.88.text:
"Did I do that?
Oh, my God, did that happen?"

412.32.text: Or what I also call "moth memories."

421.14.text:
and all of a sudden your body,
your psyche, is flooded.

426.26.text: That feeling is the opposite of flow.

430.26.text:
Death awareness gives you control
over those memories.

435.24.text:
Because if you can imagine all the way
to the end of your life,

438.72.text:
then you can back up,
and you can enjoy the good memories

443.75.text:
but you can change the endings
of the rest of them

447.41.text:
if you're imagining
all the way to the end.

450.46.text: You can clear the unfinished business

455.86.text:
You can take control
of your entire life.

458.49.text: I know it takes a lot of imagination,

461.14.text:
but I don't think
you'll have any trouble.

463.27.text:
You can decide which memories to keep
and which not.

469.08.text:
if you were free
from all the bad memories?

475.72.text: What if you only had six months to live?

478.58.text: What would you choose to do?

482.00.text:
All right, let's take
death awareness a step further.

491.21.text:
All of that knowledge, that experience,
that maintenance --

498.85.text:
That complex, excited brain
of yours silenced.

503.36.text: It's a very hard thing to do at any age.

507.50.text:
But Dr. John Barrett,
experienced with death,

512.85.text:
He said, "When I am gone, I'm just --
there's nothing left.

516.60.text: It's like the clippings, you know, of hair

519.37.text:
on the barbershop floor;
just sweep it away.

523.20.text:
If you want to know who I was,
or who I am, ask my children,

536.98.text: They make a personal treaty with death,

543.83.text:
They don't choose, most of them,
the extreme measures

550.20.text:
They choose palliative care;
they choose suicide.

554.58.text: They choose to go home and drink martinis.

561.92.text:
In England it's gin and tonics,
but it's basically the same idea.

569.62.text:
Now, if you can see a dead body,
do it, OK?

575.62.text: If you can help the dying, do it.

583.24.text:
If that's too hard, too creepy,
too morbid, then touch a dead animal.

590.60.text: Now, that probably seems even creepier.

596.62.text:
as a kid we were told
it was dirty, remember?

600.66.text: But you must touch life and death.

604.32.text:
I recently picked up the body
of a great blue heron.

610.32.text:
A neighbor had shot it with his .22
to protect his pond fish.

616.80.text: When I picked it up it was still warm.

619.74.text:
But that extraordinary bird
I had seen in flight...

623.82.text: It was like holding up a broken kite.

627.74.text:
It was weightless,
and death seems weightless.

631.69.text: It sort of flutters out there somewhere,

634.48.text:
and we don't know the drag
that it has on our life

639.92.text: if we have not made sense of it.

643.07.text:
Do you know what people look like
when they die?

647.13.text: If you've seen a dead body,

648.86.text: when the circulation stops, you shrink.

657.66.text:
It is so clear
that the person is not there,

662.53.text: that there's only a husk left.

667.46.text: If it's a good death, you're reassured.

670.62.text: If it's a hard death, you're traumatized.

674.14.text:
We think children are afraid of death,
but they're not.

681.64.text:
They already conduct burial rituals
for dead birds.

684.56.text:
The stories are to make adults
comfortable, not children.

690.38.text:
But death isn't just a myth;
death is a reality.

695.06.text:
It's not like the Easter Bunny;
it's a very different issue.

701.07.text:
And it's interesting that we're not sure
when children are old enough.

704.49.text: I'm not sure when adults are old enough.

709.76.text:
keeps many of us, I think,
waiting, hoping,

715.21.text:
postponing our life
as if there was another life.

720.86.text: We lose track, then, of this life.

723.71.text: We rush around as we keep hearing,

727.07.text:
and we buy things
to put around us, to keep us safe.

734.42.text:
Death awareness, again,
is the opposite of that emptiness.

738.15.text:
You feel alive, you feel natural,
you feel whole.

746.85.text:
you gain a passionate,
transcendent way to live.

750.64.text: You can feel it in your bones.

753.94.text:
Older people like me, you know,
we fear being weak,

757.10.text:
we fear being dependent,
we fear being in pain,

760.40.text: we feel fear of being disgusting.

763.18.text:
We don't want to die, you know,
hooked up to machines in a hospital

767.25.text:
as they're being raced
to an emergency room, you know,

773.67.text:
We want to die in our own way,
usually in our own bed.

779.38.text:
Now, the antidote to all of these fears
is really talking about them.

783.67.text:
Talk to your friends,
talk to your families,

787.24.text:
I, you know, I talked to my
15 and 16 year old grandchildren,

790.11.text:
and they said,
"We've never thought about it."

792.26.text:
And I said, "Well, you know,
just give it a minute."

796.41.text:
Because you're making
all of these decisions,

799.54.text:
and at some point,
they'll become important.

804.26.text: My mom at 93 fell down, broke her hip.

807.62.text:
They took her to the emergency room;
my son and I got the call.

810.62.text: We rush down there and she's in a gurney,

813.27.text: and we lean over the gurney and we say,

816.05.text:
"Mom, this doctor says
that he can give you a new hip."

820.64.text: And Mom says, "No, no, I'm bored.

824.42.text: I've been bored for three years.

828.10.text:
I'm ready to die.
Just get me something for the pain."

831.64.text:
So we got morphine,
and she was gone the next morning.

837.22.text: My mom had always lived her life fully.

840.42.text:
She belonged to a motorcycle group
called The Retreads.

846.79.text:
She knew how to live,
and she knew how to die.

852.38.text:
Journalist Steven Sotloff --
if you heard the story --

856.59.text:
at 31, he faced death
at the hands of ISIS.

861.63.text:
I believe he was fully aware
that he used his time in captivity

866.36.text: to make peace with his fate.

868.79.text:
But he also wanted
to give something to us.

873.07.text: These are his reported last words:

883.34.text:
The second one begins
when you realize you only have one."

888.76.text:
Writer Christopher Hitchens
at 62 was dying of cancer.

894.12.text: He wrote a frank account, and he said,

896.15.text:
"You know, the thing about death
is that you're at a really great party,

903.97.text: -- but the party is still going on."

906.84.text: Death before we're ready is tragic.

909.68.text:
But it is painful beyond belief
to face death

915.33.text: not feeling you have lived your own life.

919.92.text: There's so much sorrow and regret,

922.54.text:
whether it's for your life
or for someone else.

926.12.text:
My late husband, Ted, was diagnosed
with brain cancer at 55.

932.83.text: They told us he had nine months to live,

935.16.text:
and then not a single doctor or specialist
after that mentioned death.

940.32.text:
And Ted had never talked
about his feelings.

943.14.text: He didn't want to talk about death.

945.48.text:
He didn't really accept
that it could happen in nine months.

950.64.text:
We were unable to talk openly
about what was happening.

954.74.text:
I was unprepared;
I made so many mistakes.

959.64.text: I could have eased our journey.

962.93.text: I want you to have fewer regrets.

967.18.text:
Now, it wasn't all failure.
We created our own rituals.

972.00.text:
We had these pizza and beer
parties in the afternoon.

976.70.text:
and the amazing, wonderful fish guys
would come by and sit with us.

981.13.text: Ted gained weight, he didn't lose weight,

984.65.text:
and I said to the doctor,
"Is this a problem?"

988.77.text:
"If I had what he had,
I'd be doing what you're doing."

992.48.text: And we capped it off with ice cream.

995.29.text:
We ended up at one point
with 27 cartons on the table.

999.22.text:
Everybody had a spoon,
and we would pass them around,

1002.99.text: and we convinced a Hungarian visitor

1006.33.text: that this was a normal American ritual.

1013.48.text:
And I finally made a decision
that maybe we have to live thin,

1018.50.text: but I'm going to die chubby.

1022.50.text: It's all in the timing, OK?

1025.99.text: You have to work it out.

1028.97.text:
Only in the last days
did I understand what was on Ted's mind.

1033.90.text:
For the first time,
he talked about being afraid,

1040.77.text: I told him he would never be alone.

1043.64.text: He pulled me close as we fell asleep.

1047.52.text:
In the morning, I told him again,
and he tried to laugh.

1052.55.text: Then he slipped into a coma.

1055.00.text:
The next day, at noon,
on the winter solstice, he died.

1060.21.text: And the last words I hope he heard

1064.43.text:
were, "I will be with you;
you will never be alone."

1070.40.text:
Do you have your last words?
Do you know what you want to say?

1073.83.text: Do you know what you want to hear?

1078.56.text: Then they'll be there when you need them.

1081.82.text:
But more important,
you will start living them.

1088.49.text:
Death awareness
pulls all of humanity together.

1092.85.text: We're all part of that intricate beauty,

1097.48.text:
of life, you know,
of nature, of this planet.

1101.06.text: The light, you know, and the dark.

1104.22.text:
I'm am of an age,
when my British mother would say,

1108.27.text:
"The birds are beginning
to fall off their perches."

1114.48.text: I learned my death and dying lessons late.

1119.03.text:
I want you to learn them early;
it will enrich your life.

1124.26.text:
Know what's important to you;
minimize regret;

1132.67.text:
give a death plan to a loved one --
it's a loving thing to do --

1138.20.text:
envision your life story
all the way to the end,

1141.95.text: so you can back up and make changes;

1145.07.text:
repeat your last words;
and enjoy the party.

1150.18.text:
I hope that we can talk
and conspire together.

1155.48.text:
"Conspire" from the Latin
means "to breathe together,"

1159.26.text:
to conspire and breathe together
for a good life and for a good death.

1166.78.text:
All over this world,
every second of every day,

1174.34.text:
Now, you may feel very alone sometimes,
but you're not.

1179.84.text: You still have the immense power of life.

1187.09.text: Honor that life; talk about death.
